search_matches.text:
NEW PAGE 24
Draft #7
ZONING ORDINANCE
Chapter 3 Administration and Enforcement
Section 3-12 Administrative Conflicts of Interest
No staff member shall make a final decision on an administrative decision if the outcome of
that decision would have a direct, substantial, and readily identifiable financial impact on the
staff member or if the applicant or other person subject to that decision is a person with
whomthe staff member has a close familial, business, or other associational relationship. If a
staff member has a conflict of interest under this section, the decision shall be assigned to the
supervisor of the staff person or such other staff person as may be designated by the Village
Clerk. For purposes of this section, a "close familial relationship" means a spouse, parent,
child, brother, sister, grandparent, or grandchild. The term includes the step, half, and in-law
relationships.
Village of Alamance Zoning Ordinance
Page 22

NEW PAGE 25
Draft #7
ZONING ORDINANCE
Chapter 4 District Regulations
CHAPTER 4 DISTRICT REGULATIONS
ARTICLE 1. DSTRICTS ESTABLISHED AND INTENT
Section 4-1.
Purpose of Dividing the Village into Districts
A. For the purpose of promoting the health, safety and the general welfare of the Village of
Alamance, the Village is divided into districts within which are regulated and restricted
the
erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair and use of buildings, structures and
land, the height, number of stories and size of buildings and other structures, the
percentage of lot that may be occupied, the size of yards, courts and other open spaces, the
density of development and the location and use of buildings, structures and land for
business, industry, residence or other purposes.
B. The regulations in this ordinance are made in accordance with a comprehensive plan and
are designed to lessen congestion in the streets, to secure safety from fire, panic and other
dangers, to promote health and general welfare, to provide adequate light and air, to
prevent the overcrowding of land, to avoid undue concentration of population and to
facilitate the adequate provisions of transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks and
other public requirements. Such regulations have been made with reasonable
consideration, among other things, to the character of each district and its peculiar
suitability for particular uses and with a view to encouraging the most appropriate use of
land throughout the municipality.
Section 4-2. Removal of Territory from Village; Annexation
In the event of changes in Village limits removing territory from the Village, district boundaries
shall be construed as moving with Village limits. In the event of annexation of new areas to the
Village, such areas shall be zoned as recommend by the Planning Board and approved by the
Board of Aldermen.
Section 4-3. Establishment of Districts
The purpose of this section is to list and describe the zoning districts herein adopted. For the
purpose of this ordinance, the Village of Alamance and its one-mile extraterritorial jurisdiction
are hereby divided into the following use districts:
Village of Alamance Zoning Ordinance
Page 23

RA

NEW PAGE 26
Draft #7
ZONING ORDINANCE
Chapter 4 District Regulations
Residential/Agriculture District RA - The RA Residential/Agriculture District is established as a
low density district in which the principal use of land is for single family residences and
agriculture. Requirements in this district are designed to ensure that a rural character is
maintained.
Residential District, Low Density R20 - The R20 Residential District is established as a low
density residential district in which the principal use of land is for single family residences.
Residential District, Moderate Density R15 - The R15 Residential District is established as a
moderate density district in which the principal use is single family residences.
Residential Manufactured Home District - The R-M district shall permit Class A and Class B
manufactured homes as well as all uses permitted in the R-A district. Only a single-family house
or manufactured home shall be placed on a lot
Historic District H - The H Historic District is established as a high density single family
residential district. Property owners are urged to maintain the character in new construction,
alterations, and/or repairs.
Mixed Use District MU - The MU Mixed Use District is the Village center district established for
a mixture of commercial, office, and residential uses likely to find proximity to be mutually
beneficial. The neighborhood scale businesses and services are intended to meet some of the
basic needs of a limited residential area.
Conservation District CO - The CO Conservation District is the designated flood prone area of
the Village as shown on the Flood Hazard Maps and Flood Insurance Rate Maps of Alamance
County. Single family residential uses and bona fide farms are allowable in this district, provided
they comply with all FEMA requirements; but otherwise, land within this district is best left
undeveloped.
Industrial District I - - The I Industrial District is intended to provide for light industry,
manufacturing, and warehouse uses.
ARTICLE 2 CONDITIONAL DISTRICTS
Section 4-4. Purpose and Establishment
A.
Promotes compatibility - A Conditional District is established by rezoning a parcel to a
Village of Alamance Zoning Ordinance

Residential District, Moderate Density R15 - The R15 Residential District is established as a
moderate density district in which the principal use is single family residences.
Residential Manufactured Home District - The R-M district shall permit Class A and Class B

or manufactured home shall be placed on a lot
Historic District H - The H Historic District is established as a high density single family
residential district. Property owners are urged to maintain the character in new construction,

Mixed Use District MU - The MU Mixed Use District is the Village center district established for

NEW PAGE 27
Draft #7
ZONING ORDINANCE
Chapter 4 District Regulations
conditional district in which only the approved use with site-specific conditions is permitted.
When rezoned, the use of the property is subject to the standards and conditions imposed
as part of a legislative decision that creates the Conditional Zoning District and applies it to
a particular property.
B. Parallel Conditional Districts Established for Each Zoning District - A Conditional District,
bearing the designation CD (e.g., MU-CD), is hereby established as a parallel district for every
district established in the list of General Use districts.
C.
Owner must request; Village may identify certain uses requiring CD - In all cases, the
property owner must request rezoning to a Conditional District. This may be done under
any circumstances when the owner believes a site-specific development plan will increase
the potential compatibility of the proposed use. In some cases, the Village may identify in
advance certain uses, shown on the Table of Permitted Uses, that require rezoning to the
parallel Conditional District.
Section 4-5. Submissions
Review and approval of conditional zoning petitions involve a legislative hearing and legislative
decision by the Board of Aldermen. The review of conditional district zoning petitions shall be
undertaken in accordance with the normal rezoning procedure with the following additions:
A. Submissions: The property owner(s) must request the conditional zoning and shall submit a
master site plan that includes:
1. A boundary survey, with metes and distances showing the property's gross acreage,
current zoning classification(s), the location of adjacent public streets, railroad right-of-way,
bodies of water (ponds, lakes, streams, rivers, creeks), date of submittal, north arrow, and
vicinity map;
2. All existing and proposed easements, reservations and rights-of-way with street section and
widths;
3. Footprint of existing and proposed structures;
4. Proposed use of all land and structures, including the number and type (single-family
detached, multifamily, town homes, apartments) of residential units and/or the total square
footage of any nonresidential development:
5. All setbacks, buffers, screening, and landscaping required by Village regulations and/or
conditions proposed by the petitioner;
6.
Building materials, façade, signage, design features that evidence compatibility with the
surrounding area.
7. All existing and proposed access points to public streets and traffic control devices;
8. Generalized drainage plan of existing and proposed drainage patterns, buffers, delineation of
regulatory floodplains, delineated wetlands, riparian buffers and open space;
9. Proposed phasing, if any;
Village of Alamance Zoning Ordinance
Page 25

Page 25

NEW PAGE 28
Draft #7
ZONING ORDINANCE
Chapter 4 District Regulations
10. General location and number of parking spaces and circulation plan;
11. A statement in each petition analyzing the reasonableness of the proposed conditional
zoning. The statement shall include, but not be limited to, the following: (a) the conditional
zoning's compatibility with the adopted Plan of the Village; (b) the benefits and detriments
of the conditional zoning for the subject property, neighboring properties, and the
surrounding community; and (c) the conditional zoning's compatibility with the existing
land uses on adjacent and neighboring tracts.
12. Reference to provisions, in any Village or County comprehensive plan or other applicable
plans that refer to or anticipate impacts reasonably expected to be generated by the
development or use of the site.
B.
The Administrator or other designated staff member may waive an application requirement
where the type of use or scale of the proposal makes providing that information unnecessary or
impractical.
C. In the course of evaluating a petition for conditional zoning for a proposed use or development, the
Village may request additional information from the petitioner related to: number and location of
all structures, exterior features, building materials, architectural style, signage and any
additional information needed to demonstrate that conditional zoning will minimize particular
impacts and protect both the immediate area and the community as a whole.
D.
Minor modifications in conditional district standards that do not involve a change in uses
permitted or the density of overall development permitted may be reviewed and approved
administratively. Any other modification of the conditions and standards in a conditional
district shall follow the same process for approval as are applicable to zoning map
amendments. (NCGS 160D-703(b))
Section 4-6. Community Meeting
The Village shall sponsor an information meeting involving the developer, Planning Board, and
adjacent property owners. The purpose of the informal meeting is to provide a time for
adjoining property owners to meet with the developer and the Village staff to review
preliminary proposals before they are presented at a public hearing conducted by the Board of
Aldermen. Notices of this Information Meeting shall be sent by First Class mail at a minimum to
all adjoining property owners.
Section 4-7. Review and Approval
A.
Review and Approval Process: The review and approval of a petition for a conditional zoning
district shall follow the same legislative process as outlined for a general use rezoning.
Conditional zoning district decisions shall be made in consideration of identified relevant

ZONING ORDINANCE
Chapter 4 District Regulations
Section 4-12. Notes to Table of Permitted Uses Development Standards
The Development Standards in these Notes provide regulations and conditions must be verified by the
Zoning Administrator in order for a zoning permit to be issued. The purpose of these conditions is to
assure that certain uses which may have complexity, or are potentially incompatible with their
surroundings, meet the specified restrictions. Each use with required development standards shall
comply with the regulations of the district in which it is located and with the requirements specified in
these Notes.
Note 1. Accessory Uses and Structures - In residential districts
a. Accessory structures shall be located in a rear yard not less than five (5) feet from the
rearlot line. The side yard setback shall be the same as for the side yard setback for the
districtwhere located, provided that in no case shall the structure be located within
20 feet of any street right-of-way.
b. Structures except for utility substations or similar structures shall not be located
within any easement.
C. Separate structures must be located a minimum of 10 feet away from the principal
building.
d. Such structures shall cover not more than thirty percent (30%) of the rear yard.
e. Built-in swimming pools are not considered accessory structures.
Note 2. Bed and Breakfast), Air B and B
a. A Bed and Breakfast home (B and B) or Air B and B shall not be located within four
hundred (400) feet of a rooming house, boarding house or another tourist/guest
home.
b. The B and B or Air B and B must be owned by the property owner who also resides
onthe property.
C.
The use shall be located in a structure which was originally constructed as a
dwelling.
d. Meals served on the premise shall be for guests of the facility.
e. There shall be no exterior advertising except that which is permitted for a home
occupation.
Note 3. Churches
a. A Church or other place of worship may be allowed in a Residential District subject
to the requirements of the district where it is located and provided that the
structure shallhave minimum side and rear yards of fifty (50) feet and a front yard
at least twenty-five (25) feet greater than that required for a single-family
residence within the district, andthat the off-street parking requirement of this
ordinance are met.
b. An outdoor play area for a church in any zoning district shall be enclosed by a

NEW PAGE 32
Draft #7
ZONING ORDINANCE
Chapter 4 District Regulations
between the main tracks;
6. District boundaries indicated as approximately parallel to or extensions of features
indicated in subsections 1 through 5 above shall be so construed and at such
distance therefrom as indicated on the Official Zoning Map. Distance not specifically
indicated on the Official Zoning Map shall be determined by the scale of the map.
7. Where a district boundary divides a lot which was in single ownership at the time of
passage of these regulations, the Board of Adjustment may, as a special exception,
permit the extension of the regulations for either portion of the lot not to exceed
fifty feet beyond the district boundary line into the remaining portion of the lot.
Section 4-10. Interpretation of District Regulations Applicable to Unlisted Uses
The procedure provided for below shall be used to determine if an unlisted use shall be
permitted within the Village's Zoning jurisdiction. Additional uses in character with a district
may be added to this Ordinance by amendment.
Findings by the Board of Aldermen: Where a particular use category or use type is not listed or
closely aligned to a use in the Permitted Uses Table, the Administrator shall make a
recommendation to the Board of Aldermen at the next scheduled meeting as to whether the
proposed use should be permitted or denied. The Board of Aldermen shall make the final
decision after considering the following criteria:
1. intent of the Ordinance concerning the district(s) involved
2. the character of the proposed use
3. the impact of the proposed use on the zoning district taking into consideration:
a. the type, size and nature of buildings and structures;
b. the impact on adjacent properties created will not be greater than that ofother
uses in the zoning district;
C. parking requirements and traffic generation;
d. whether the intensity, volume, size or the operation or activity has thepotential
to be a nuisance to the surrounding properties
Following determination by the Board, the property owner/applicant shall be immediately
advised of the decision
